deliberation: I checked whether the devastation language is literal or figurative. The verbs for shame and terror are applied to cities/fortresses, which creates personification, but there are no similes or extended metaphors beyond that.

instances.hebrew_text: הֹבִישָׁה נִלְכְּדָה קִרְיָתָיִם הֹבִישָׁה הַמִּשְׂגָּב וָחָתָּה
instances.english_text: Kiriathaim captured and shamed, the stronghold shamed and dismayed!

instances.explanation: The cities and stronghold are spoken of as if they can feel shame and terror, personifying the urban centers to highlight Moab’s humiliation.

deliberation: I looked for wordplays and also for conceptual metaphors. I found metonymic uses (Heshbon for its people; Moab’s praise for its reputation; the sword for warfare). The rest is fairly literal planning of destruction.

instances.english_text: Moab’s glory is no more

ground: loss of what made Moab commendable

instances.english_text: In Heshbon they have planned evil against her

association of locale with its ruling class
instances.explanation: The place-name ‘Heshbon’ stands metonymically for its inhabitants/leaders who are doing the planning.

instances.english_text: The sword is following you
target: pursuing military destruction of the town ‘Madmen’
ground: sword represents attacking armies and killing
instrument stands for the act of war
instances.explanation: The ‘sword’ stands metonymically for warfare and violent death that will overtake the city.

deliberation: I examined whether ‘voice of crying’ or ‘destruction and great breaking’ might be metaphorical. They function here as literal descriptions of alarm and ruin, without non-literal comparison or personification.
I checked the verb ‘is broken’ used of Moab; it cannot be literal, since a nation is not a physical object. This yields a clear metaphor; the rest (crying young ones) is literal suffering language.

instances.english_text: Moab is broken
ground: loss of structural integrity and ability to function
instances.explanation: Moab is likened to a breakable object that has been shattered, conveying its total defeat and helplessness.

deliberation: The ascent and descent locations with weeping and cries appear to be literal geographic-route descriptions of fleeing people. I did not find a clear non-literal comparison or personification distinct from the narrative description.
I looked at the imperative to flee and the comparison with Aroer. The simile ‘be like Aroer in the desert’ is the key figure, conveying isolation/desolation; the rest is straightforward exhortation.

instances.english_text: And be like Aroer in the desert
vehicle: the town Aroer in the wilderness
ground: lack of protection or population density
posture: urgent prophetic counsel to seek survival even in desolation
instances.explanation: Moab’s people are urged to become like the desolate town of Aroer in the wilderness, picturing their future isolation and exposure.

deliberation: I considered whether trust in ‘works and treasures’ was idiomatic; it reads literally as misplaced reliance. The notable figure is the treatment of Chemosh’s ‘exile’, which uses the god’s name metonymically for his cultic statue/people.

instances.hebrew_text: וְיָצָא כְּמוֹשׁ בַּגּוֹלָה כֹּהֲנָיו וְשָׂרָיו יַחְדָּיו

deliberation: The verse speaks of a destroyer coming to every city and the valley/tableland being devastated. These are literal images of conquest and environmental ruin; I did not identify figurative comparisons beyond ordinary descriptive language.

I focused on the unusual command ‘give wings to Moab’, which clearly cannot be literal. In context, it pictures Moab as a bird needing wings to flee, a compact metaphor; the rest of the verse is literal desolation language.

instances.english_text: Give wings to Moab, for she must go hence
target: Moab as a nation needing to escape
ground: rapid flight and attempt to escape danger
instances.explanation: Moab is envisioned as a bird that would need wings to flee, underscoring both the urgency to escape and the futility of such attempts.

deliberation: I examined ‘work of YHWH’ and ‘withholds his sword from blood’. The former is standard for divinely commissioned action. The latter uses ‘sword’ and ‘blood’ metonymically for warfare and killing.

instances.english_text: Cursed be he who withholds his sword from blood!

ground: the sword stands for fighting, blood stands for lethal force
instrument and result represent the whole act of battle
posture: divine insistence on thorough execution of judgment
instances.explanation: The ‘sword’ represents warfare and ‘blood’ represents killing; together they figuratively denote full participation in the divinely mandated battle.

deliberation: This verse develops an extended wine metaphor: Moab is like wine resting on its lees, not poured from vessel to vessel; his taste and aroma remain. These attributes are not literal of a nation, so it is a sustained metaphor, not multiple unrelated figures.

instances.hebrew_text: שַׁאֲנַן מוֹאָב מִנְּעוּרָיו וְשֹׁקֵט הוּא אֶל־שְׁמָרָיו וְלֹא־הוּרַק מִכְּלִי אֶל־כֶּלִי ... עַל־כֵּן עָמַד טַעְמוֹ בּוֹ וְרֵיחוֹ לֹא נָמָר

ground: stability, unshaken existence, and fixed character
lack of disturbance leading to entrenched qualities
posture: critical observation of Moab’s complacent security
instances.explanation: Moab is likened to wine that has long rested undisturbed on its dregs, so that its ‘flavor’ and ‘aroma’—its entrenched character—have remained unchanged.

deliberation: This continues the wine metaphor: ‘tilters’ will pour him out, empty his vessels, and shatter jars. Moab is treated as wine in containers; the invaders are the pourers. I treat this as one coherent metaphorical extension.

instances.hebrew_text: וְשִׁלַּחְתִּי־לוֹ צֹעִים וְצֵעֻהוּ וְכֵלָיו יָרִיקוּ וְנִבְלֵיהֶם יְנַפֵּצוּ

vehicle: wine being poured out and jars smashed
posture: assertion of God’s direct orchestration of Moab’s upheaval
instances.explanation: Moab is depicted as wine in jars that will be poured out and shattered, signifying the complete emptying and destruction of the nation and its settlements.

deliberation: I examined the shame language and the reference to Bethel. ‘Bethel’ functions as a metonymy for its idolatrous cult, the object of Israel’s misplaced trust, paralleled with Chemosh for Moab.

instances.english_text: as the House of Israel were shamed because of Bethel, on whom they relied

ground: sacred site stands for its cultic system and object of trust
failure of the cult equals shame of the worshipers
posture: didactic reminder of Israel’s past failure
instances.explanation: ‘Bethel’ stands metonymically for the idolatrous shrine and its cult, which had been Israel’s false object of trust.

deliberation: The verse is a rhetorical question challenging Moab’s self-perception as warriors. In context (imminent defeat), it is ironic: their boast contrasts with reality. There is no explicit metaphor, but there is rhetorical irony.

instances.hebrew_text: אֵיךְ תֹּאמְרוּ גִּבּוֹרִים אֲנַחְנוּ וְאַנְשֵׁי־חַיִל לַמִּלְחָמָה

instances.explanation: The question is ironic: Moab calls itself mighty warriors precisely when it is about to be crushed, exposing the emptiness of the boast.

deliberation: I assessed ‘gone down to the slaughter’. The ‘slaughter’ (טָּבַח) evokes animal butchering and is applied to Moab’s young men, creating a metaphor for ruthless killing in battle.

instances.english_text: His choice young men have gone down to the slaughter

posture: divine portrayal of Moab’s defeat as dehumanizing
instances.explanation: The deaths of Moab’s young men in battle are compared to animals being taken to slaughter, stressing the merciless and overwhelming nature of their defeat.

deliberation: The ‘doom’ of Moab drawing near is temporal language that can be taken straightforwardly as approaching judgment in time. I did not see a distinct metaphor beyond conventional phrasing of something ‘coming’.
I focused on ‘the strong rod is broken, the lordly staff’. Rod/staff here symbolize Moab’s power or ruling authority, so we have a metaphorical transfer from physical staff to political strength.

instances.english_text: Alas, the strong rod is broken, the lordly staff!
target: Moab’s ruling power and national strength
vehicle: a strong, splendid staff or rod
ground: the staff supports and rules, and when broken loses its function
loss of capacity to lead and defend
instances.explanation: Moab’s power is pictured as a strong, glorious staff that has been broken, signifying the end of its capacity to rule or protect.

deliberation: I noted two distinct figures: (1) ‘daughter of Dibon’ is a standard personification of the city; (2) ‘sit in thirst’ pictures the city as enduring parched deprivation, a metaphor for the effects of siege or devastation.

instances.english_text: O inhabitant, daughter of Dibon
target: the city of Dibon and its population
vehicle: a ‘daughter’ as a young woman addressed directly
ground: city treated as a female person with status and vulnerability
instances.explanation: Dibon is personified as a ‘daughter’, a young woman, giving the city a personal, vulnerable identity in the judgment speech.

instances.english_text: Descend from glory and sit in thirst

vehicle: a woman stepping down from an exalted place to sit parched with thirst
ground: loss of honor and comfort, replaced by humiliation and deprivation
posture: divine command to accept humiliation as deserved judgment
instances.explanation: The city is portrayed as a woman leaving a position of ‘glory’ to sit in physical thirst, a metaphor for loss of status and resources after devastation.

deliberation: The inhabitant of Aroer is addressed directly and told to question fleeing people. This can all be taken literally (witnessing refugees); I did not detect a non-literal comparison or emblematic use of Aroer here beyond that.
I checked the shame and fear language. The nation ‘Moab’ is said to be shamed and terrified, which is a mild personification of a collective as experiencing human emotions.

instances.english_text: Moab is shamed and dismayed
target: the nation Moab as a whole
ground: shared experience of acute embarrassment and fear
posture: prophetic proclamation of Moab’s emotional downfall
instances.explanation: Moab, as a nation, is portrayed as a person who feels shame and terror in response to its overthrow.

deliberation: This is a bare announcement that judgment has reached certain regions and towns. ‘Judgment’ here is judicial action and can reasonably be read literally for divine punishment; no distinct figurative trope stands out.
The verse simply lists further cities affected; there is no explicit figurative comparison, personification, or idiomatic phrase here.
As with the preceding verse, this is a list of cities without additional descriptive imagery. I did not identify figurative language in this line.

The verse continues the list and sums up ‘all the cities of the land of Moab, far and near’. The ‘far and near’ forms a merism conceptually for totality, but it is so conventional that I judged it borderline; I treat it as ordinary comprehensiveness rather than a separate figure here.
Two distinct symbolic body parts are used: Moab’s ‘horn’ is cut off and his ‘arm’ is broken. Both are metaphors for strength, and they are separate expressions, not just two words for the same item.

instances.english_text: The horn of Moab has been cut down
ground: the horn symbolizes strength and dominion; its removal means loss of power
posture: divine declaration of the end of Moab’s power
instances.explanation: Moab’s political/military power is symbolized as an animal horn that has been cut off.

instances.english_text: and his arm is broken
target: Moab’s capacity to act and fight
vehicle: a human arm that is broken
ground: broken arm implies inability to exert force or defend oneself
posture: emphatic completion of the previous metaphor
instances.explanation: Moab’s ability to act militarily is depicted as an arm that has been broken, indicating total incapacitation.

deliberation: I saw (1) the ‘drunk’/‘vomit’ imagery used metaphorically of the nation under judgment; and (2) Moab becoming ‘a laughingstock’, a metaphorical status of being turned into an object of ridicule.

instances.english_text: Get him drunk, for he vaunted himself against the LORD. Moab shall vomit till he is drained

ground: loss of control, disgrace, and physical abasement
judgment causing Moab to be publicly humiliated and emptied
instances.explanation: Moab’s judgment is portrayed as intoxication leading to vomiting—an image of humiliating, uncontrollable downfall due to its arrogance against God.

instances.english_text: And he too shall be a laughingstock

posture: reversal of Moab’s prior contempt for others (esp. Israel)
instances.explanation: Moab is depicted not just as being laughed at but as embodying ‘a laughingstock’, a metaphorical status of being an object of ridicule.

deliberation: I focused on Israel being ‘a laughingstock’ and the gesture of ‘shaking the head’ when speaking of him. Together they form an idiomatic/metaphorical expression for derisive mockery.

instances.hebrew_text: הַשְּׂחֹק הָיָה לְךָ יִשְׂרָאֵל ... כִּי־מִדֵּי דְבָרֶיךָ בּוֹ תִּתְנוֹדָד

ground: habitual ridicule and contempt expressed nonverbally and verbally
posture: God’s indictment of Moab’s mocking attitude toward Israel
instances.explanation: Calling Israel a ‘laughingstock’ and describing Moab as ‘shaking the head’ at him is an idiomatic way to speak of contemptuous mockery.

deliberation: I looked at the command to leave cities and dwell in rock, and especially the explicit comparison: ‘be like a dove that nests in the sides of a pit’. That is a clear simile for fearful hiding in inaccessible places.

instances.english_text: Be like a dove that nests in the sides of a pit

instances.explanation: Moab’s people are urged to imitate a dove that hides its nest in the rocky sides of a pit, emphasizing their fearful retreat into inaccessible refuges.

deliberation: The piling of terms for pride culminates in ‘height of his heart’ (רוּם לִבּוֹ). That uses vertical imagery of height for arrogance, a conceptual metaphor.

instances.english_text: and his self-exaltation (lit. ‘the height of his heart’)

connection between height and arrogant self-elevation
posture: divine criticism of Moab’s excessive pride
instances.explanation: Moab’s proud attitude is conceptualized as an elevated or ‘high’ heart, using spatial height as a metaphor for arrogance.

deliberation: The verse speaks of Moab’s wrath/insolence and that his boasts are not true. These can be read literally about his behavior and lies; I did not identify a distinct non-literal vehicle or comparison.
‘I will howl/cry/moan for Moab’ can be taken as literal prophetic lament (either Jeremiah’s or YHWH’s). There is strong emotional language but not a clear metaphor or simile in this line itself.

This verse personifies ‘vine of Sibmah’ and speaks of its tendrils crossing the sea—imagery for the extensive reach of Moab’s viticulture/trade and the lament over its loss. It forms a single extended metaphor/personification.

instances.hebrew_text: מִבְּכִי יַעְזֵר אֶבְכֶּה־לָּךְ הַגֶּפֶן שִׂבְמָה נְטִישֹׁתַיִךְ עָבְרוּ יָם עַד־יָם יַעְזֵר נָגָעוּ עַל־קֵיצֵךְ וְעַל־בְּצִירֵךְ שֹׁדֵד נָפָל

ground: wide extension, richness, and vulnerability to being cut down
economic reach and productivity like sprawling tendrils
posture: lament over the loss of Moab’s luxuriant prosperity
instances.explanation: The ‘vine of Sibmah’ is personified and its tendrils are said to cross the sea, picturing the far-reaching prosperity and trade of Moab’s vineyards now devastated by a destroyer.

deliberation: ‘Joy and gladness are gathered from the vineyard/land’ uses removal verbs normally for people and applies them to emotions, and ‘the shout is no shout’ is rhetorical. I treat the personified removal of joy as the main figure.

instances.hebrew_text: וְנֶאֶסְפָה שִׂמְחָה וָגִיל מִכַּרְמֶל וּמֵאֶרֶץ מוֹאָב

ground: loss of festivity and celebration that once accompanied harvest
complete absence of former positive emotions
posture: sorrowful depiction of the depth of devastation
instances.explanation: Joy and gladness are treated like beings that can be taken away from the land, personifying these emotions to stress their total disappearance.

deliberation: The place-names frame a geographic sweep of outcry. The phrase ‘the Waters of Nimrim shall become desolations’ treats the waters themselves as transformed into a wasteland, a compact metaphor for dried-up streams.

instances.explanation: The waters are said to ‘become desolations’, picturing the drying up of vital streams as if they themselves turned into wasteland.

deliberation: The verse literally states that God will put an end to those who go up to high places and offer incense. These are straightforward cultic actions; I did not discern figurative language here.
The key figure is the explicit simile ‘my heart moans for Moab like flutes’, repeated for Kir-heres. The heart is personified as producing music-like sounds of lament.

instances.hebrew_text: לִבִּי לְמוֹאָב כַּחֲלִילִים יֶהֱמֶה וְלִבִּי אֶל־אַנְשֵׁי קִיר־חֶרֶשׂ כַּחֲלִילִים יֶהֱמֶה

heartfelt grief expressed as music-like moaning
posture: compassionate lament even in the context of judgment
instances.explanation: The heart is portrayed as moaning in a way likened to the sound of mourning flutes, personifying the inner emotion and comparing it to ritual music.

deliberation: The bald heads, shorn beards, gashes, and sackcloth describe known mourning practices and can be taken literally as predicted behavior; I did not isolate a distinct metaphor beyond that cultural code.
After literal mourning on the roofs and squares, God says, ‘I have broken Moab like a vessel in which there is no delight’. That is an explicit simile using Moab as a broken, worthless vessel.

instances.english_text: For I have broken Moab like a vessel no one wants
target: Moab’s national existence and value among nations
vehicle: a useless vessel thrown away because no one desires it
ground: complete breakage and worthlessness, discarded by its owner
instances.explanation: Moab is compared to a broken, unwanted vessel, emphasizing both its total ruin and the fact that no one values or wants it anymore.

deliberation: ‘Moab will be a laughingstock and a horror’ assigns to Moab a metaphorical status as something people mock and are appalled at; this echoes earlier ridicule imagery.

instances.english_text: Moab shall be a laughingstock and a shock to all those near him

spectacle people deride and are appalled at
ground: people respond to Moab with both ridicule and horrified astonishment
Moab’s fall becomes a warning example
posture: prophetic portrayal of Moab as cautionary example
instances.explanation: Moab is said to ‘be’ a laughingstock and a horror, characterizing its new identity as something people both mock and fear as a warning.

deliberation: I identified an explicit simile: the attacker is likened to an eagle that swoops and spreads wings over Moab, a common biblical image for swift, overpowering invasion.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנֵּה כַנֶּשֶׁר יִדְאֶה וּפָרַשׂ כְּנָפָיו אֶל־מוֹאָב

ground: speed, height, dominance from above, inescapable strike
posture: warning of the unstoppable nature of the invader
instances.explanation: The invader is compared to an eagle swooping down and spreading its wings over Moab, symbolizing swift and dominating conquest.

deliberation: After literal city capture, the clause ‘the heart of Moab’s warriors shall be like the heart of a woman in travail’ compares hardened soldiers to a woman in labor, a clear simile for anguish and weakness.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהָיָה לֵב גִּבּוֹרֵי מוֹאָב בַּיּוֹם הַהוּא כְּלֵב אִשָּׁה מְצֵרָה

vehicle: the heart of a woman in labor

posture: humiliating reversal of expected masculine bravery
instances.explanation: The warriors’ hearts are likened to a woman in labor, underscoring their extreme anguish and loss of courage in the day of judgment.

deliberation: Moab’s being ‘destroyed from being a people’ is literal language of national extinction. The phrase ‘he magnified himself against the LORD’ uses ‘magnified’ metaphorically for arrogance/exaltation.

instances.english_text: For he magnified himself against the LORD

ground: self-exaltation as if increasing one’s greatness over proper bounds
posture: divine condemnation of Moab’s overreaching pride
instances.explanation: Moab is said to ‘magnify himself’ against God, using physical enlargement as a metaphor for arrogant self-exaltation.

deliberation: The triad ‘terror, pit, and snare’ are listed as coming upon Moab; they are literal dangers but also prepare for the extended trap metaphor in the next verse. Here the line can still be read as a list of calamities, so I assign no separate figure.

instances.explanation: Attempts to escape judgment are portrayed as an animal fleeing one danger only to fall into pits and snares, emphasizing the inescapability of God’s ‘year of punishment’.

deliberation: I found (1) ‘fire went forth from Heshbon, flame from Sihon’—warfare as consuming fire—and (2) ‘it devoured the brow/crown of Moab’—Moab’s frontier and leaders as body/head imagery. These are two related but distinct metaphors.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי־אֵשׁ יָצָא מֵחֶשְׁבּוֹן וְלֶהָבָה מִבֵּין סִיחוֹן

ground: war sweeping out like fire from a city
posture: poetic evocation of traditional taunt-song imagery
instances.explanation: The military aggression emanating from Heshbon/Sihon is portrayed as ‘fire’ and ‘flame’, stressing its destructive, spreading power.

instances.hebrew_text: וַתֹּאכַל פְּאַת מוֹאָב וְקָדְקֹד בְּנֵי שָׁאוֹן

deliberation: The verse laments Moab and says ‘the people of Chemosh are undone’, which literally refers to Moab as defined by its god. The captivity and exile of sons and daughters are concrete; no clear metaphor is introduced here beyond that national-theological label.

The idiom ‘restore the fortunes’ / ‘turn the captivity’ (שָׁבַתִּי שְׁבוּת) is a standard metaphor for radically reversing a people’s situation. It is not literal physical turning but figurative for comprehensive restoration.

instances.english_text: But I will restore the fortunes of Moab
vehicle: ‘turning back’ captivity/fortune as if it were a physical object moved back
ground: comprehensive reversal from calamity to well-being
change of circumstances likened to turning something around
posture: promise of eventual mercy following judgment
instances.explanation: ‘Restore the fortunes’ (literally ‘turn the captivity’) is an idiomatic metaphor for reversing a people’s disastrous condition and bringing them back to favor.
